Conservatives need to find a way to appeal to young people, Prime Minister Theresa May has admitted. 
And this will be one of themes of the Conservative conference in Manchester this week. 
In a pre-conference interview, Mrs May said: “I think there is a generation out there who feel that they’re going to be worse off than their parents. And what we want as Conservatives is that people should be able to see a brighter future for their children.” 
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn’s success in appealing to younger voters is seen as one of the reasons the Tories lost their majority in June’s General Election while Labour gained 30 seats. British Prime Minister Theresa May (Image: Getty Images Europe) 
Here we look at what to expect from the Tory conference, which runs from October 1-4. 
Conference to become a leadership contest 
Conservatives are still in power. But the conference will be something of a post-mortem, as Tory MPs and activists try to figure out what went wrong. 
And the question of the party leadership will be on everyone’s minds. 
It’s widely assumed that Theresa May will stand down at some point before the next election, perhaps shortly after Brexit takes place in March 2019. 
Conservatives will naturally be thinking about what happens after that. It means speeches by potential leadership candidates, such as Home Secretary Amber Rudd, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson or Brexit Secretary David Davis, will be watched particularly closely. Police and security at Manchester Central before the Conservative Party conference (Image: MANCHESTER EVENING NEWS) 
Theresa May wants to return to the theme of social justice 
The highlight of the conference will still be on Wednesday, when the Prime Minister delivers her speech. 
Her theme will be “building a country that works for everyone”. 
Mrs May hopes to show that there is more to her Government than Brexit. 
When she first became Prime Minister, in July 2016, she delivered a speech promising to fight “the burning injustices” of modern Britain. 
This included the difference in living standards between the rich and the poor, the fact that women earn less than men and the difficulty young people face in buying a house. 
And the Prime Minister will attempt to show that she hasn’t forgotten about this promise. Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson (Image: Getty Images Europe) 
How the North will be represented 
Social justice will also be the theme of a debate involving Guy Opperman, MP for Hexham in Northumberland. Read More Outspoken new North East MP has 'quite a future' in politics, says Tom Watson 
He will speak at a fringe event organised by think tank Bright Blue titled “From burning injustice to social justice”. 
Mr Opperman will also take part in fringe events looking at changes to the pensions system, in his role as a Pensions Minister. 
And fellow Northumberland Tory, Berwick MP Anne-Marie Trevelyan, will take part in a debate about the sort of agriculture and forestry policies the UK should have after Brexit. 
But they aren’t the only people who want to talk about the North during the conference. 
Ben Houchen, the Conservative elected as mayor of Tees Valley earlier this year, will join former Chancellor George Osborne and others for a major debate on the Northern Powerhouse. 
Mr Osborne was the architect of the policy, which was designed to improve the economy of the North of England, largely by improving transport links between the major cities 
It will be a chance for him to comment on how the Government has handled the Northern Powerhouse idea since he left the Government. Read More The key messages from Jeremy Corbyn's speech at Labour's annual conference 
Mr Houchen will also take part in a debate looking at how mayors can help big cities succeed, where he will be joined by West Midlands mayor Andy Street. 
Right-wing political magazine The Spectator is holding a debate on whether the Northern Powerhouse policy can still deliver. 
And a body calling itself the Conservative Arts and Creative Industries Network will hold a debate on the Northern Powerhouse and the creative industries. Like us on Facebook
